The administration of intramuscular doses of M72/AS01E-4 vaccine is designed to activate the immune system by the vaccine delivery system and the adjuvant. The recombinant protein antigens expressed by the M72 recombinant protein vaccine are introduced into antigen-presenting cells and presented to CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, which are important for providing effective immune responses against M.tb infection. The AS01E-4 adjuvant is a nano-emulsion-based adjuvant system that consists of 95% squalene and surfactant emulsifiers polysorbate 80 and Tween 85 (25% of the squalene's volume). AS01E-adjuvanted vaccines have a good safety profile and the capacity to induce strong systemic and mucosal immune responses . The use of intramuscular doses instead of subcutaneous or intradermal doses is justified by the fact that M72/AS01E-4 vaccine is expected to stimulate antigen-presenting cells capable of presenting antigens to CD4+ and CD8+ T cells more efficiently at the deep tissues rather than at the surface layer of the skin.

model_response: That sounds right! For the design details, we've already covered the fact that this is a prospective observational study. Do you have any other information to add? For example, the study setting, location, provider(s) involved, and the plan for data collection?

The five study arms in the original manuscript were as follows: Arm 1: patients who are successfully decannulated; Arm 2: patients who are successfully decannulated, but have dysphagia; Arm 3: patients who are successfully decannulated but have neurocognitive deficits; Arm 4: patients who undergo weaning but are not decannulated; and Arm 5: patients who are not weaned at all and are not decannulated.

For the second study arm, you can refer to the first arm. The reasoning behind this arm is to assess the outcomes of tracheostomy decannulation when performed using the standard clinical practice of the participating hospital, without specifically targeting dysphagia prevention. This information can serve as a basis for comparison with the outcomes obtained from the third arm using standard dysphagia prevention measures.

The third study arm would be patients who are not tracheostomized but are hospitalized at the Swiss Paraplegic Center Nottwil within the project's data collection period. The intervention/treatment would be observation, with an emphasis on the decannulation process. This arm focuses on the observations of tracheostomized patients being cared for at the Swiss Paraplegic Center Nottwil, including their decannulation process as compared to non-tracheostomized patients hospitalized at the same center. This allows for the evaluation of the potential challenges faced by non-tracheostomized patients, which could inform the development of strategies to support the entire decannulation process, including patient education and support.

For the fourth study arm, the participant group/arm would be cognitively impaired patients who cannot sufficiently comment on their medical situation. The intervention/treatment would involve obtaining medical data directly from caregivers instead of the patients. This arm addresses the specific need for effective decannulation care in cognitively impaired patients by considering alternative sources of medical information and potentially developing strategies to adapt the decannulation process to the specific needs of this patient group.

Finally, for the fifth study arm, the participant group/arm would be patients who did not develop or did not have tracheal stenosis. The intervention/treatment would involve their exclusion from the study. This arm guarantees that patients who do not fulfill the studied criteria (that of developing tracheal stenosis) are not subjected to evaluations beyond their relevance.

Overall, the five study arms that we have designed for this observational study include: group A: adult tracheotomized in-patients (≥ 18 years) with any medical diagnosis with tracheostomy management and decannulation process; group B: patients who undergo decannulation in the Swiss Paraplegic Center Nottwil during the project's data collection period with post-decannulation follow-up; group C: patients with a communication language of German, French, Italian, or English who require decannulation; group D: patients who provide consent to participate in the study; and, finally, group E: patients for whom decannulation is sought at the Swiss Paraplegic Center Nottwil. Each of these study arms has its own significance and helps to achieve the study aim of assessing the effectiveness of tracheostomy decannulation outcomes at the Swiss Paraplegic Center Nottwil.

model_response: Got it! Have you selected a design for your clinical trial yet? If not, I'd recommend a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design. An RCT is a superior design to cohort designs when assigning cause–effect relationships to treatments, where confounding factors are better addressed. It also prevents confounding bias by using allocation concealment during the recruitment and randomized assignment to treatment/placebo among study participants. There are several types of RCT designs: parallel RCTs, crossover, factorial, and stratified. Parallel RCTs recruit participants to treatment and placebo cohorts. Crossover trials involve a single cohort of participants that are randomly assigned to either treatment or placebo at separate visits. The advantage of a cross-over design is that it doesn't require participants to receive both treatments. Factorial RCTs evaluate two treatments by randomly assigning participants to treatment and control groups. Finally, stratified RCTs recruit participants in different subgroups (strata) to assign treatment and control groups. The two main reasons for including the stratification factor is that the treatment effect varies by subgroup and the risk of disease varies by subgroup. As your trial is a randomized controlled trial in phase 2 and you will recruit thrombocytopenia patients into treatment and placebo cohorts, I would recommend using a parallel RCT design.

As discussed earlier, the experimental intervention will involve implants with a machined transcortical portion and the active comparator will include implants with a roughened transcortical portion. Both types of implants will undergo bone consumption followed by bone expansion procedures in each study arm. However, the timing and approach of bone consumption and bone expansion will vary between the two study arms. For the experimental group, the implants with a machined portion will be placed first, and then the bone consumption procedure will be initiated. After enough bone volume is obtained, the implants will be subsequently prepared to receive a dental crown by the bone expansion procedure. This sequence of bone consumption first followed by bone expansion is chosen based on previous research by Abbasian et al.  and Dahiya et al. .

The research question of the clinical trial that you are designing is to compare the clinical and radiographic outcomes of dental implants placed in edentulous narrow ridges using single-implant-supported mandibular complete fixed-bridge restorations. In addition to that, the aim is to study the bone remodeling between various implant surfaces. In this context, the experimental arm, namely, Rex Ti implant (with a machined surface transcortically), will be used in this trial to compare it with the active comparator arm, namely, Rex Ti-3 implant (with a roughened surface transcortically). These two implant-system options have shown good results in clinical studies and meta-analyses performed in the last 5 years. The study protocol will provide a scientific answer on which of the two implant-surface modifications, the machined or roughened, is superior in achieving better results in single-implant-supported mandibular complete fixed-bridge restorations placed in edentulous narrow ridges. In this context, the rationale for choosing Rex Ti implant as the experimental arm is that some evidence suggests that implants with roughened surfaces may provide a more secure and stable platform for supporting the restoration, particularly in situations with limited bone density or compromised bone quality. Thus, it is important to assess whether or not these implant surface modifications indeed provide additional benefits in terms of bone remodeling. The rationale for choosing Rex Ti implant as the active comparator arm is that it has a different surface topography, and it has shown good results in previous research. Therefore, this design provides an opportunity to carry out a direct comparison between the effects of these two implant surface modifications on the clinical and radiographic outcomes.

Phase 3 trials typically involve more participants compared to phase 2 trials. model_response: Certainly! The experimental treatment, total pulpotomy, is a common procedure used in clinical settings to manage irreversible pulpitis. The procedure involves removing the coronal pulp tissue and placing a biocompatible material (in this case, MTA) in the pulp chamber. This material promotes blood clotting in the chamber and serves as a barrier layer between the irreversibly damaged pulp tissue in the root canal and the coronal tissues. The main advantage of total pulpotomy over root canal treatment is that it is simpler and less invasive. This treatment may also preserve pulp vitality and enable pulpal–dentin regeneration . In some cases, total pulpotomy with MTA has been shown to improve pulp sensibility and vitality and to reduce post-treatment symptoms .

Great choice! A controlled randomized clinical trial can provide valuable information about the effectiveness of total pulpotomy in managing post-operative pain and pulpitis in mature molar teeth. Compared to root canal treatment, which is the conventional approach, total pulpotomy is a simpler and less-invasive option. However, both treatments have benefits and drawbacks that we can examine in the controlled study.

Maitland's mobilization is a passive accessory mobilization technique in which the practitioner uses their hand, finger, or thumb to apply pressure to the joint, which is moved passively under minimal impulse . The technique consists of a graded series of movements, from a free-floating motion towards the end of the physiological range of motion to a full oscillatory technique. There are three grades of pressure applied: free-floating, impulsive, and oscillatory. The technique can be used on all moving joints and involves a set of standardized procedures performed by clinicians with post-graduate training in manipulative medicine .

For Interferential therapy, the parameters are as follows: electrodes with different shapes and sizes and are applied at the motor points of the muscles around the injured area. The frequency is 75 Hz for the active electrode and 100 Hz for the larger one, with the frequency increased gradually to 80 Hz for the active and 100 Hz for the passive electrode. The duration of the treatment is 20 min.

Mulligan's mobilization technique includes three steps: motion phase, hold-release phase, and static compression phase. In the motion phase, the therapist performs a passive range of motion. In the hold-release phase, the therapist holds a break for a period of time while maintaining the joint. In the static compression phase, the therapist applies a constant pressure or tension to the joint or soft tissue.

Excellent. Now let's discuss the study design. Clinical trials can be divided into two primary categories: observational and interventional. Observational trials, such as case-control and cohort studies, do not involve the use of an intervention. Instead, these studies aim to observe and describe the natural course of a particular medical condition. On the other hand, interventional trials evaluate the effectiveness of a particular intervention. They can be further classified into two subcategories: therapeutic and diagnostic trials. Therapeutic trials evaluate the effectiveness of a therapeutic intervention to determine its potential health benefits. This interventional approach can include surgical procedures, behavioral interventions, medical devices, or pharmacological agents. model_response: Alright. Interventional clinical trials typically occur in different phases. Phase 0 is the administration of new drugs and dosage to provide information for the drug development process. Phase I trials are conducted on a small number of healthy individuals to test the safety of the drug and its dosage. Phase II trials are conducted on a small number of patients to confirm the drug's effectiveness. Phase III trials are conducted on a larger number of patients to further investigate the safety and efficacy of the drug. Finally, Phase IV trials are conducted after the drug has been approved and marketed to monitor its long-term effects and gather post-market data.

model_response: Ok, observational studies can be designed in several ways, including case-control, cross-sectional, longitudinal, and cohort study designs. The choice of study design depends on the question your study aims to answer and the availability of data. For instance, case-control studies involve two groups: case and control groups, where the controls are participants who do not have the disease or condition that is being investigated. These studies are typically used to determine if an exposure or factor is associated with a specific outcome or disease. On the other hand, cohort studies compare disease risk factors between two groups of patients, one group exposed and another group not exposed. The study participants are followed over time to determine if those exposed to a specific risk factor develop the disease more than those not exposed. Cross-sectional studies are similar to cohort studies but only collect data on the study participants at one time point. Cohort studies and case-control designs are usually used to identify a cause-effect relationship between an exposure and a disease. Longitudinal studies assess the change in disease or risk factors over time.
I also suggest including the age of the patients. You can set an inclusivity level for age depending on your target population.

The aim is to collect data on what is considered the standard of care for the condition, and compare it to the results of the experimental arm. The reasoning behind having an active comparator is to improve validity of results. The "Experimental: DIAPI" arm is where the experimental intervention, the DIAPI algorithm, will be applied. Patients in this arm will have their diabetes management determined by the DIAPI algorithm during the peri-procedural period rather than by receiving usual care. DIAPI is designed to take into account a patient's personal characteristics, such as their age, weight, and HbA1C reading, and provide evidence-based, timely recommendations for care during the peri-procedural period. The DI API algorithm can be implemented as a standalone solution or integrated into existing healthcare information technology systems such as electronic medical record systems and telemedicine platforms. The objective of the DIAPI study arm is to demonstrate the efficacy and safety of DIAPI in managing diabetes during the peri-procedural period compared to usual care. By comparing the outcomes of patients receiving DIAPI to those receiving usual care, we can assess whether using the DIAPI algorithm actually leads to better health outcomes (e.g. lower HbA1C levels, fewer hospitalizations) rather than using usual care.

For the "dietary quality" arm, we can measure the effect of our proposed text-based intervention on 2 main outcomes: (1) participants' adherence to recommended dietary guidelines and (2) their overall dietary quality. We can measure participants' adherence to dietary guidelines, such as consumption of fruits and vegetables, using a questionnaire to collect participants' self-reported intake of these foods. Previous studies have found that both fruit consumption and vegetable consumption are generally low in cancer survivors (Vinhual et al., 2015; Vaughan et al., 2016). To improve participants' fruit intake, we can follow other studies that suggest that cancer survivors should be encouraged to eat at least the recommended daily servings based on the US dietary guidelines for the total fruit or fruit and vegetables combined. For example, Lin et al. (2015) promoted cancer survivors to consume at least a fruit or vegetable with every meal, as recommended by the 2003 Dietary Guidelines for Americans (USDA and DHHS, 2015), which helped them to achieve their recommended servings of whole grains, fruits, and vegetables. To encourage vegetable intake, we can follow Lin et al.'s (2015) recommendation, which found that promoting portion size increased cancer survivors' vegetable intake. For example, we can encourage cancer survivors to try to eat a vegetable with every meal. Moreover, we can encourage cancer survivors to consume vegetables with protein sources, such as beans or lentils, because the combination of these foods may provide them with more nutrients, such as vitamin C and iron (Tucker et al., 2012).

Absolutely. In the second arm, the participant group/arm would be targeted at caregivers of cancer survivors who report difficulty engaging in dietary quality behaviors. Of course! The rationale for using bronchoscopy with peripheral airway biopsy as the treatment/intervention arm is that it allows for non-invasive access to the small airways of the lungs. Previous studies have indicated that the peripheral subpleural areas of the lungs are the most common sites of pathology in patients with parenchymal lung disease, including sarcoidosis [1, 2]. This is an important finding, as the diagnosis of sarcoidosis is primarily based on histopathological findings, such as non-necrotizing granuloma [3, 4]. However, it can be challenging to access small airway pathologies using biopsy methods, such as lung transbronchial needle aspiration (BAL) [5, 6]. Biopsies via BAL are less common in sarcoidosis patients, resulting in a lower sensitivity . It has been difficult to obtain histological confirmation of sarcoidosis from peripheral subpleural lung areas affected by granulomatous lung disease in both clinical and research settings .

It is important to screen for cataracts not only for the sake of the patient's overall eye health but also to ensure an accurate glaucoma diagnosis, as an undiagnosed and untreated cataract can mimic disease, leading to glaucoma misdiagnosis. I'm glad you asked! The reasoning behind these specific study arms, particularly, the Escalation followed by the Expansion arms (POTENT), is to ensure the right dose has been selected for the combination therapy before moving forward to a larger trial. It also ensures that each arm has an appropriate sample size based on the statistical plan.

Part B - Expansion will be the main part of the trial, as it will involve the largest number of patients. In this arm, we will include patients who have progressed on systemic anticancer therapy for metastatic disease, specifically on platinum-based chemotherapy. We will evaluate the efficacy of the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab and compare it to the treatment that physicians and patients face today, which is a combination of Tepotinib and the anti-PD-L1 agent Pembrolizumab. Additionally, we will also assess the safety of the treatment in this arm. As part of this arm, we will stratify the patients based on their disease biomarkers, including genomic biomarkers and PD-L1 levels. We will not enroll patients in both study arms. They can only participate in part A or part B, but not both.

In Part A - Escalation, the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab will be administered with Tepotinib being taken orally at multiple doses of 50 mg/day, 100 mg/day, 150 mg/day, or 200 mg/day, and Pembrolizumab being administered at a fixed dose of 200 mg by intravenous infusion. We will follow a 21-day cycle to allow adequate time for the drug to take effect and assess side effects. In each cycle, patients will receive 200 mg of Pembrolizumab on Day 1 and take Tepotinib on a continuous dosing schedule from Day 5 through Day 28.

For Part B - Expansion, patients diagnosed with MET exon 14 skipping mutation will receive the combination of Tepotinib and Pembrolizumab daily for three weeks. Subsequently, they will undergo Pembrolizumab treatment during a 21-day cycle. By targeting this specific genetic mutation, we can assess the potential efficacy and safety of the combination in MET-positive patients.

Certainly! Here are the study arms for the POTENT trial: Part A - Escalation:- Arm 1: Tepotinib 300 mg daily plus Pembrolizumab 200 mg Q3W Part B - Expansion - Arm 2: Tepotinib 500 mg daily plus Pembrolizumb 200 mg Q3W

It provides a structured, safe, and personalized learning method that aims to teach participants how to manage their coughs through lifestyle modifications, such as cough hygiene, behavioral and environmental modifications, and management of triggers. The program starts off with weekly treatment videos, followed by daily treatment videos for two weeks. The participants will be asked to practice the training exercises and to fill out daily paper forms. The whole program lasts two months. All the education and training videos are uploaded onto the YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/CHS6YUJR_j9-5gk3694B-ZbXd7j8uR4iE).

The sham comparator arm is designed to match the experimental arm as closely as possible in terms of frequency of intervention exposure, intervention delivery, and intervention quality. In the sham group, participants will view similar videos showing the comparison treatment education content and will not receive any treatment or training exercises. They will be instructed to follow the same weekly schedule for watching the videos as participants in the experimental group and will complete the progress check questions in the same way. This will help ensure that any outcomes seen in the study are due to iBCST and not other factors, such as study participant expectation or attention bias.

It is critical that the experimental intervention being studied is compared to another intervention. This allows us to determine the effectiveness of the experimental intervention. It is important to use a control intervention rather than simply having no treatment because this ensures that any potential changes in outcomes observed over the course of the study are due to the difference between the experimental and sham comparator arms. Without a sham comparator arm, the effects observed may be due to natural course of the condition or even other unrelated external factors, such as other treatments.

While using non-random allocation (e.g. consecutive order of enrollment or allocation based on age and gender) might be easier for participant enrollment and data analysis purposes, it could introduce selection biases. These biases can have a significant impact on the conclusions drawn from the study results, as the sample may not accurately represent the target population.

The FTB block involves injections of ropivacaine into the deep fascia between the sartorius muscle and the femoral triangle (FT) to block the femoral nerve, femoral artery, and femoral vein. The IPACK block aims to prevent postoperative pain and is performed by injecting a mixture of bupivacaine (50 ml) and lidocaine (20 ml) into the space between the iliac, psoas, and quadratus lumborum muscles. model_response: Sure! For the continuous serratus anterior plane block arm, the study subjects will receive an ultrasound-guided continuous serratus anterior plane block. This will involve the following steps:

Well, the purpose of this interventional study is to compare the pain management effectiveness of an ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block with an intravenous dexmedetomidine infusion in postoperative rib fracture patients. Serratus anterior plane blocks are well-established and proven to be effective in pain management of postoperative patients, as evidenced in studies that show they aid in pain control and decrease opioid consumption among patient populations who undergo many different types of surgery including chest, abdomen, and shoulder surgeries.[1, 2, 3, 4, 5] Additionally, there are numerous studies that indicate that ultrasound-guided blocks are effective in pain management and reduce opioid consumption in postoperative patients.[6, 7, 8, 9, 10] Therefore, it's a proven and effective treatment strategy for pain management in postoperative rib fracture patients and was selected as the first arm for comparison in this study.

The second study arm is the Comparison Control: Dexmedetomidine group. In this arm, patients will receive continuous infusion of dexmedetomidine for pain management. The dexmedetomidine will be administered at a rate of 0.6 µg/kg/hr with a target arousal score of 1–2 (scale range of 1–10).

Dexmedetomidine is a preferred drug for analgesia and sedation for intensive care patients. It has been shown to be effective in reducing the requirement for opioid analgesia in patients with chronic pain. Dexmedetomidine also has many advantages over other modalities including cost-effectiveness, easy use, and quick onset of action. Therefore, I believe that dexmedetomidine infusion would be beneficial for pain control in patients with multiple rib fractures, and this provides a good basis for comparison with other intervention alternatives.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms: 1. Intervention (US-guided Serratus Plane Block) Group S: An ultrasound located serratus block will be performed with the patient in a side-lying position with initial monitoring, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation (SpO2). The anterior axillary line will be identified. The probe will be placed in the anterior axillary line to ensure a deep view of the ribs. The ribs will be located with the ribs parallel to the probe. With in-plane guidance, a 100-3 MHz linear probe will be used to insert a 22G Quincke spinal needle at the fifth or sixth intercostal space (between T7 and T10), in the sagittal plane, with the point of insertion approximately at the level of the ninth or tenth rib. After identification of the plane, approximately two to three milliliters of negative pressure will be applied to check for a free flow of the solution. With the needle still in place, a total of two milliliters per kilogram of 2 % levobupivacaine solution will be injected. The needle will be removed afterward. The post-block block-up test should be re-positive for up to 20 minutes. Afterwards, the patients could be given a bolus of fentanyl 50 micrograms every ten minutes for breakthrough pain.2. Intervention (Dexmedetomidine) Group D: After initial monitoring, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation (SpO2), the patient will receive a loading dose of 0.6 micrograms/kilogram/hour of dexmedetomidine for up to 10 minutes. After receiving the loading dose, the patient will then receive a continuous infusion of 0.2 micrograms/kilogram/hour dexmedetomidine. All patients will receive either fentanyl or acetaminophen at the discretion of the attending anesthesiologist for breakthrough pain.
